question: How much water should I drink every day?
initial_answer: To avoid dehydration, adults should drink a minimum of 2-3 Litres of water per day, or at least 8 cups a day. All drinks such as tea, coffee, and fruit juice count towards this total (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 26) [1]. Children should drink all the time as they need (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 26) [2].

All drinks such as tea, coffee, and fruit juice count towards this total (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 26) [1]. Children should drink all the time as they need (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 26) [2].

question: What should I avoid eating if I have high blood pressure?
initial_answer: To avoid high blood pressure, you should avoid eating too much salt, too much sugar, and too much fatty red meat (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 43) [1]. You should also avoid foods which are poor value for money such as food containing only energy, e.g., sodas and many artificial soft drinks (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 41) [7].
final_answer: To avoid high blood pressure, you should avoid eating too much salt, too much sugar, and too much fatty red meat (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 43) [1]. You should also avoid foods which are poor value for money such as food containing only energy, e.g., sodas and many artificial soft drinks (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 41) [7].

question: What's a quick healthy lunch I can make for work?
initial_answer:
Here are some suggestions for a quick, healthy lunch:
*   Take a fruit and a serving of vegetables (100g or one handful of fresh vegetables) (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 43) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 43) [3].
*   Consider a mixed meal with a variety of food types from the main three food groups: energy giving, body building, and protective foods (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 43) [3].
*   You can prepare any tuber (Irish potatoes, sweet potatoes, cassava, yams) the same way as matooke (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 89) [9].
*   Consider family incomes and lifestyles, individual habits and preferences, nutritional/health status, and daily routines such as work and school when planning a meal (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 40) [5].
final_answer:
Here are some suggestions for a quick, healthy lunch:
*   Take a fruit and a serving of vegetables (100g or one handful of fresh vegetables) (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 43) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 43) [3].
*   Consider a mixed meal with a variety of food types from the main three food groups: energy giving, body building, and protective foods (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 43) [3].

question: How much protein do I need if I don’t work out?
initial_answer: The recommended intake of protein each day is about 1 gram per kilogram of body weight (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 17) [1]. For example, if you weigh 60 kilograms (132 lbs), you will require 60 grams of protein each day (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 17) [1]. This is equivalent to one egg or a piece of meat about the size of an egg (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 17) [1].
final_answer: I don't know.

question: I feel tired all the time. Is it because of my diet?
initial_answer: Yes, it could be related to your diet. Individuals with iron deficiency anaemia become tired easily and cannot work for longer hours (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 35) [1]. Good nutrition is important because it enhances physical and cognitive development (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 27) [7]. A person with poor nutrition may experience a reduced ability to work and earn a living (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 27) [4].

A person with poor nutrition may experience a reduced ability to work and earn a living (Food & Nutrition Handbook, p. 27) [4].
